Thus have I heard. Once, the BhagavÄn, the Omniscient One, was in RÄjagá¹›ha

on Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a Mountain. By means of his supernormal powers, he manifested a vast, extensive, pure, unobstructed site of enlightenment, together with innumerable great assemblies, expounding the profound Dharma door of the aggregates of the sense faculties.
At that time, in the assembly there was a bodhisattva named Firm Pure Faith, who rose from his seat, adjusted his robes, bared his right shoulder, joined his palms, and said to the Buddha:
I now wish to ask about something in this assembly. I request to consult with the World-Honored One. Please grant me permission.
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Ask as you wish, and you may speak.
The bodhisattva Firm Pure Faith said:
As the Buddha said before:
'After I pass away, after the true Dharma has disappeared, as the semblance Dharma is about to end, and as we enter the degenerate age,

at that time, sentient beings will have meager blessings, with much decline and distress, the lands will be in frequent turmoil, disasters will occur repeatedly, and various calamities and fears will be pressing upon them.
My disciples will lose their wholesome thoughts, only increasing greed, anger, jealousy, and arrogance.

Even if there are those who seem to practice wholesome dharmas, they will only seek worldly benefits and fame, taking them as their main focus, unable to single-mindedly cultivate the essential Dharma for liberation.

At that time, sentient beings will see the world's calamities and turmoil, their minds always weak, worried and fearful for themselves and their relatives, unable to obtain clothing and food to sustain their lives.
Because of these many obstacles and causes and conditions, in the Buddha's teachings, those with dull faculties and little faith, those who attain the Way, are extremely few.
Even those who gradually attain faith in the Three Vehicles are also very rare.
All those who cultivate worldly meditations and give rise to spiritual powers, and those who know their past lives, will gradually disappear.
In this way, later, entering the Dharma-ending age for a long time, attaining the Way, gaining faith, meditation, spiritual powers, and so forth will all be completely lost.
I now ask the TathÄgata for this future evil age, when the semblance Dharma is about to end and the Dharma-ending age has arrived, for those with a little wholesome faculty.
What expedient means are there to enlighten, guide, and cause them to give rise to faith, to eliminate misfortune and distress?
Because those sentient beings encounter an evil age with many obstacles, they turn away from wholesome thoughts.
In the worldly and supramundane causes and effects, they frequently give rise to doubt and are unable to single-mindedly seek wholesome dharmas with a firm mind.
Such sentient beings are pitiable and should be saved.
The World-Honored One has great compassion and is omniscient!
I pray that you will give rise to expedient means to enlighten them.
To cause them to leave the net of doubt, eliminate all obstacles, and increase their faith.
According to whichever vehicle, they will quickly attain irreversibility.
The Buddha told Firm and Pure Faith:ğŸ”½Excellent!
Excellent!
You have asked about this matter well, and it deeply accords with my intention.
In this assembly now, there is a Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva named Ká¹£itigarbha. You should ask him about this matter.
He will establish skillful means for you, reveal and explain it, and fulfill your wishes.
Then the Bodhisattva Firm and Pure Faith again said to the Buddha:
The TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, has unsurpassed great wisdom!
Why do you not explain it yourself, but rather wish for Ká¹£itigarbha Bodhisattva to expound it?
The Buddha told Firm and Pure Faith:
Do not give rise to thoughts of superiority or inferiority.

This good man has already generated the mind of enlightenment incalculably long ago, beyond measure, beyond thought, beyond comparison, and has long since been able to cross the ocean of omniscience and fulfill his merits.
But he relies on the power of his original vows and skillful means to manifest transformations, responding like a reflection to the ten directions.

Although he universally travels to all lands and always engages in meritorious deeds, he has a special affinity for benefiting beings in the evil world of the five turbidities, also due to the power of his original vows and the karmic affinity of beings to be transformed.
For eleven eons he has been adorning this world and maturing beings.
Therefore, in this assembly, his physical appearance is upright and majestic, surpassing all except the TathÄgata.
And in the transformative work in this world, only the great bodhisattvas such as Samantabhadra and AvalokiteÅ›vara can match him.

By the power of this bodhisattva's original vows, he can quickly fulfill all the wishes of sentient beings, eliminate all their grave offenses, remove all obstacles, and bring them present peace and comfort.
Moreover, this bodhisattva is called the one who speaks with good comfort.
This means that he skillfully expounds the profound Dharma and is able to skillfully guide those who first give rise to the intention to seek the Great Vehicle, causing them not to be timid.
For these and other causes and conditions, sentient beings in this world yearn for him, accept his teachings, and attain liberation.
Therefore, I now instruct him to speak.
At that time, Bodhisattva Firm Pure Faith, having understood the Buddha's intention, immediately requested Ká¹£itigarbha Bodhisattva MahÄsattva, saying:
Excellent, savior of the world, true person!
Excellent, great wisdom bodhisattva!
As I have asked:
'In the evil world, by what skillful means do you guide sentient beings, causing them to leave behind all obstacles and attain firm faith?'
The TathÄgata now wishes to have you explain this skillful means.
You should know the time has come, and out of compassion, explain it.
At that time, Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Ká¹£itigarbha said to Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Firm Pure Faith:
Good man!
Listen attentively.
I will explain it for you.

If after the Buddha's extinction, in the evil world, there are bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, upÄsakas, and upÄsikÄs who have not attained definitive faith in the worldly and world-transcending causes and effects, and are unable to cultivate the perception of impermanence, the perception of suffering, the perception of non-self, and the perception of impurity, and do not realize them;
They are unable to diligently contemplate the four noble truths and the twelve links of dependent origination;
They also do not diligently contemplate the true nature, the ultimate reality, non-arising, non-ceasing, and other such dharmas.
Because they do not diligently contemplate such dharmas, they are unable to ultimately not commit the ten evil fundamental offenses.
They are unable to have single-minded faith in the various realms of the merits of the Three Jewels.
Among the Three Vehicles, they all lack direction.
For such people, if there are various obstacles and increasing worries, or doubts or regrets, their minds are unclear in all situations.
Seeking much and being troubled, entangled by many affairs, their actions are uncertain, their thoughts are disturbed, and they neglect the practice of the Way.

Those who have such obstacles and difficulties should use the method of the wooden wheel to discern good and evil karmas from past lives, and current happiness and suffering, good and bad events, etc.
Because of the convergence of conditions, there is existence; when conditions are exhausted, it ceases.
Karmic accumulation follows the mind, and the characteristics of the results arise.
It is neither lost nor destroyed, and the characteristics correspond without error.
Thus, discern the good and evil karmic retributions, and enlighten one's own mind.
Regarding doubtful matters, use this to reach a conclusion.
If the Buddha's disciples only learn such Dharma, with utmost sincerity they take refuge, and what they observe is all true.
They should not abandon such Dharma, but instead follow worldly divination, various auspicious and inauspicious predictions, and greedily indulge in them.
If one indulges in them, it deeply obstructs the noble path.
Good sons!

Those who wish to learn the characteristics of a wooden wheel should first carve a piece of wood about the size of a finger, making it less than one inch long, with the middle four sides flat, and the rest gradually tapering towards both ends.
Hold it sideways and throw it up, making it easy to spin, and for this reason it is called a wheel.

Moreover, relying on this characteristic, one can destroy sentient beings' wrong views and doubts, turn towards the right path, and reach a place of peace and security, and for this reason it is called a wheel.
The characteristics of the wheel are of three kinds of distinctions.
What are the three?
First, the wheel pattern can show the differences in the good and evil karmic seeds created in past lives, and that wheel has ten.
Second, the wheel pattern can show the near and far, strong and weak, and large and small differences in the karmic actions accumulated in past lives, and that wheel has three.
Third, the wheel pattern can show the differences in the retributions received in the three periods of time, and that wheel has six.
If you wish to contemplate the differences in the good and evil karmic actions created in past lives, you should carve ten wheels out of wood.
Based on these ten wheels, write down the names of the ten wholesome [deeds].
Each wholesome [deed] is the main [topic] in one wheel, and is recorded on one side.
Next, write down the ten unwholesome [deeds] to correspond with the ten wholesome [deeds], and also record them on one side each.
As for the ten wholesome [deeds], they are the root of all wholesome [actions] and can encompass all other wholesome dharmas.
As for the ten unwholesome [deeds], they are also the root of all unwholesome [actions] and can encompass all other unwholesome dharmas.
If you wish to consult the wheel signs, you should first learn to sincerely pay homage to all Buddhas in the ten directions with a focused mind.
Then make the vow:
'May all sentient beings in the ten directions quickly be able to draw near and make offerings, and receive the true Dharma.'
Next, you should learn to sincerely pay homage to all Dharma treasures in the ten directions with a focused mind.
Then make the vow:
'May all sentient beings in the ten directions quickly be able to uphold and recite, practice in accordance with the Dharma, and explain it to others.'
Next, you should learn to sincerely pay homage to all sages in the ten directions with a focused mind.
Then make the vow:
'May all sentient beings in the ten directions quickly be able to draw near and make offerings, give rise to the bodhi mind, and be determined not to regress.'
Afterwards, you should learn to sincerely pay homage to the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Ká¹£itigarbha with a focused mind.
Then make the vow:
'May all sentient beings in the ten directions quickly eliminate heavy evil karma and grave offenses, and be free from all obstacles.
May they be fully provided with all necessities.'
Having made such prostrations, one should then make offerings with whatever incense, flowers, etc. one has.
As for making offerings, one should contemplate that the essence of all the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha treasures is eternally pervasive and omnipresent.
One should wish that this incense, flowers, etc. be the same as the nature of phenomena, universally perfuming all Buddha lands, and performing the activities of the Buddha.
One should also contemplate that all offering implements in the ten directions are always present.

I will now use all the various kinds of incense, flowers, necklaces, banners, canopies, precious adornments, various kinds of music, lamps, candles, food and drink, clothing, bedding, and medicine that exist in the ten directions, and all the various kinds of offering implements that exist in the ten directions, imagining them from afar, and together with all beings, I will respectfully make offerings.
I should think of all the worlds where there are those who cultivate offerings, and I will now rejoice in them.
If there are those who have not yet cultivated offerings, I wish to be able to guide them to cultivate offerings.

Moreover, I wish that my body will be able to quickly reach all buddha lands, and to all the Dharma and Sangha, each with all kinds of adornments and offering implements, together with all beings, I will hold them up and offer them.

Making offerings to all the Dharma bodies, physical bodies, relics, images, stupas, and all the Buddha's activities, making offerings to all the Dharma treasures and places where the Dharma is expounded, making offerings to all the noble Sangha assemblies, vowing to practice such offerings together with all sentient beings, and gradually attaining accomplishment in the six perfections and the four immeasurable minds.
Deeply understanding that all phenomena are originally quiescent, unborn, unceasing, of a single flavor and equality, free from thought and pure, ultimately perfect.
You should also specifically focus your mind on making offerings to our Bodhisattva Mahasattva Ksitigarbha.
Next, you should chant his name, either reciting it silently or
single-mindedly addressing him, saying:
'Homage to Bodhisattva Mahasattva Ksitigarbha.
' Chant his name like this, completing it up to a thousand times.
After a thousand recitations, say this:
'Bodhisattva Mahasattva Ksitigarbha!
Great compassion!
May you protect and remember me and all sentient beings, quickly remove all hindrances, increase pure faith, and make the present observation accord with reality.
Having spoken these words, then take the wooden wheel in the hand and throw it sideways on a clean surface.
In this way, if one wishes to observe oneself, or if one wishes to observe others, it is all like this.
One should know that the signs of the wheel are to be observed according to the present karma. One should carefully contemplate and examine each and every one.
Either purely endowed with the ten wholesome [deeds], or purely endowed with the ten evil [deeds], or with wholesome and evil mixed, or with the wholesome incomplete, or with the evil incomplete.
Such karmic causes have different types, and the habitual tendencies and fruits of retribution are each different, as extensively explained elsewhere by the World-Honored Buddha.

One should remember and contemplate the present karmic seeds, and the past experiences of suffering, happiness, good fortune, and misfortune, as well as the habitual tendencies of afflictions and karma that correspond to the present fruits of retribution. Those that correspond are called corresponding;
If it does not correspond, it means not being sincere, which is called false and mistaken.

If the signs of the wheel are divined, and neither good nor evil karma appears, this person has already realized the wisdom of the uncontaminated mind, is solely seeking liberation, and no longer delights in receiving worldly rewards. All contaminated karma gradually weakens and does not increase further, and therefore does not appear.

Moreover, for those who are neither purely good nor purely evil, the good and evil karma that does not appear for these two types of people are all weak and unable to attract results, and therefore do not appear.

If in the future the disciples of the Buddha have divined the corresponding signs of good and evil karmic results, and when they obtain what they desire in terms of the five desires and requisites, they should not indulge themselves and give rise to negligence.
They should immediately contemplate:
'Because of such good karma from my past lives, I now obtain this reward.
I should now further cultivate and advance, and should not rest.'

If one encounters various calamities, misfortunes, and unsettling events, and is troubled and frightened, and things do not go as one wishes, one should willingly accept it and not let doubt and regret cause one to turn away from cultivating wholesome deeds.
One should then contemplate:

It is only because I created such evil karma in my past lives that I now receive this retribution. I should now repent of that evil karma, focus on cultivating its antidotes and other wholesome deeds.
I should not dwell in laziness and indulgence, further accumulating various heaps of suffering.
This is called the method of the first wheel of divination and examination of signs.
Good man!

If one wishes to examine and discern the near and far, strong and weak, and distinctions in size of karma accumulated in the past, one should again carve three wheels out of wood, each with one's body, speech, and mind in charge of one wheel, and record it with written characters.
Also, in the center of the wheel, on one side, write one line, making it coarse and long, penetrating the edge.
Next, on the second side, draw a line, making it fine and short, not reaching the edge.
Next, on the third side, make a side incision like a line, making it coarse and deep.
Next, on the fourth side, also make a side incision, making it fine and shallow.
Know that good karma is adorned like a painting, and evil karma is harmful like an incision.
The long and large painting shows that accumulating goodness has been for a long time, and the practice and karma are intense and superior.
The fine and short painting shows that accumulating goodness has been for a short time, and one has just begun to practice and is dull, and what one does is slight and thin.
The coarse and deep incision shows that practicing evil has been for a long time, and what one does is superior, and the remaining misfortune is also thick.

The fine and shallow incision shows that turning away from goodness has been for a short time, and one has just begun to practice evil dharmas, and the karma one does has not yet reached a superior level.
Even if one gives rise to grave evil, if one has already repented, this is called minor evil.
Good sons!

If one divines the first wheel's characteristics, one only knows the good and bad distinctions of the karma created in past lives, but one cannot know the length of time accumulated, the strength, size, or smallness of the karma created. Therefore, one must divine the second wheel's characteristics.
If divining the second wheel's characteristics, one should rely on the karma manifested in the first wheel's characteristics.
If it belongs to the body, cast the body wheel's characteristics;
if it belongs to the mouth, cast the mouth wheel's characteristics;
if it belongs to the mind, cast the mind wheel's characteristics.
One should not use the characteristics of these three wheels to cast them all at once.
One should follow the principal karma, each good and evil, and cast them separately according to the wheel to which they belong.

Furthermore, if in the first wheel's characteristics one only obtains the body's good, and in this second wheel's characteristics one obtains the body's evil, it means that one lacks sincerity and does not attain harmony, which is called false and erroneous.

Moreover, the incompatible means that in the first wheel, one obtains the karma of not killing and the karma of stealing. If one first observes the karma of not killing, but in the second wheel, one obtains the body of evil, it is called incompatible.

Furthermore, if one observes that from birth in the present, one does not enjoy the karma of killing and has no sin of killing, but the mind is the master of the karma of killing, and in this second wheel, one obtains the great evil of the body, it is called incompatible.
The meaning of the incompatibility of the remaining verbal and mental karmas should also be understood in the same way.
Good son!

If sentient beings in the future wish to seek liberation from birth, old age, sickness, and death, and have just begun to cultivate the mind, practice meditation, and cultivate the wisdom of signlessness, they should first observe the amount and heaviness of the evil karma they have created in their past lives.
If one's unwholesome karma is thick, one cannot immediately study meditation and wisdom, but should first cultivate the method of repentance.
Why is this?
Because this person's past habitual evil mind is fierce, so in the present he must create much evil and violate the grave precepts.
Because of violating the grave precepts, if one does not repent and make them pure, and then cultivates meditation and wisdom, there will be many obstacles and one will not be able to attain success.
Or one may lose one's mind and become confused, or be disturbed by external evil, or accept evil teachings and increase evil views.
Therefore, one should first cultivate the method of repentance. If the precepts are pure and the grave sins of past lives are reduced, then one will be free from obstacles.
Good sons!
Those who wish to cultivate the method of repentance should stay in a quiet place and adorn a room according to their ability.
Place Buddha images and scriptures inside, hang silk banners and canopies, gather incense and flowers to cultivate offerings.
Wash the body and clothes, do not let them be smelly or dirty.
During the daytime, in this room, recite the names three times.
Single-mindedly respectfully bow to the seven buddhas of the past and the fifty-three buddhas.
Next, according to the ten directions, each returning in general, imagining the mind to universally bow to all the buddhas' physical bodies, relics, images, stupas, temples, all Buddha's activities.
Next, again universally bow to all the buddhas of the ten directions and three times.

Also, one should imagine the mind to universally bow to all the Dharma treasures of the ten directions, next one should imagine the mind to universally bow to all the sages of the ten directions, and then further specifically call the name and bow to my Ká¹£itigarbha Bodhisattva MahÄsattva.
Having bowed like this, one should confess one's faults and single-mindedly declare:
May the great compassionate Honored Ones of the ten directions bear witness and protect me. I now repent and will not commit them again.

I wish that I and all sentient beings may quickly eliminate the ten evil deeds, the four grave offenses, the five heinous crimes, the inverted views, the slander and destruction of the Three Jewels, and the offenses of icchantikas from immeasurable eons past.
One should further contemplate:
Such offenses arise only from false and inverted thoughts. There is no definite reality that can be obtained. They are originally only empty and quiescent.
I wish that I and all sentient beings may quickly reach the fundamental mind and forever eliminate the roots of offenses.
Next, one should further give rise to the vow of encouragement and request:
I wish that all Bodhisattvas in the ten directions who have not yet attained perfect enlightenment may quickly attain perfect enlightenment.
If they have already attained perfect enlightenment, I wish that they may always abide in the world, turn the wheel of the true Dharma, and not enter nirvana.
Next, one should further give rise to the vow of sympathetic joy:
'May I and all sentient beings forever abandon the mind of jealousy, and in the three times and all lands, joyfully rejoice in all the merits cultivated and accomplished.'
Next, one should make the vow of dedication:
'May all the merits I cultivate benefit all sentient beings, together heading for the Buddha's wisdom and reaching the city of nirvana.'
Having made the vow of dedication in this way, one should then go to another quiet room, sit upright with a focused mind, either chanting or silently reciting my name.
One should reduce sleep. If one has much drowsiness, one should circumambulate and recite in the ritual arena.
Next, at the time of the night, if there are things such as lamps and candles, one should respectfully make offerings during the three periods and repent and make vows.
If one cannot provide things such as light, one should be in another quiet room, single-mindedly reciting.
Practice this repentance method day after day, do not be lax or negligent.

If a person has distant roots of goodness from past lives, and temporarily encounters evil conditions to create evil dharmas, with light karmic hindrances, a vigorous mind, and strong willpower, after seven days, they will attain purity and remove all obstacles.
Such beings have various degrees of karmic thickness and sharpness of faculties, with innumerable distinctions.
Some may attain purity after two seven-day periods;
some may attain purity after three seven-day periods, up to seven seven-day periods.
If one has heavy past and present offenses, they may attain purity after one hundred days;
some may attain purity after two hundred days, up to one thousand days.

If those with extremely dull faculties and the heaviest karmic hindrances are only able to arouse a courageous mind, disregard their bodies and lives, always diligently chant and recite, circumambulate day and night, reduce sleep, repent and make vows in repentance, enjoy cultivating offerings, do not slack off or neglect, and even to the point of losing their lives, they must not give up.
If they make progress in this way, they will definitely attain purity within a thousand days.
Good sons!
If you wish to know the signs of attaining purity, after seven days of initial practice, you should place the second wheel mark in your hand and throw it three times each day at dawn.
If body, speech, and mind are all purely good, it is called attaining purity.

In this way, future sentient beings who are able to practice repentance have each cultivated goodness in the Buddha Dharma since the distant past, and according to the various merits they have cultivated, their karma has various differences in thickness.
Therefore, when they attain purity, the signs are also not the same.
There may be sentient beings who attain the three karmas to be purely good, but they do not immediately attain the other good signs.
There may be sentient beings who attain the three karmas to be good signs, and in one day and one night, they will again see the light filling their room.
Or they will smell a special and unusual fragrance, and their body and mind will be refreshed.
Or they will have a good dream, and in the dream they will see the Buddha's physical body come to bear witness for them, and with his hand he will pat their head and exclaim:
Excellent!
You are now pure, and I have come to bear witness to you.
Or they will dream of the bodhisattva's body coming to bear witness for them, or they will dream of the Buddha's image emitting light to bear witness for them.
If a person has not attained the three karmas to be good signs, but only sees and hears such things first, then it is false, deceptive, and fraudulent, and not a good sign.

If there are people who have previously established the basis for supramundane goodness, and their minds are concentrated and sharp, then I will at that time manifest my body according to their capacity for being liberated.
Emitting the light of great compassion, causing them to be at ease and free from all doubts and fears.
Sometimes manifesting spiritual powers and various transformations, sometimes causing them to recollect the events of their past lives, the good and evil they have done.
Sometimes, according to their preferences, expounding various profound and essential teachings for them.
At that time, they will attain definitive faith in the direction they are facing, and gradually realize the fruits of the path of Å›ramaá¹‡as.

Furthermore, if those sentient beings are not yet able to see my transformed body expounding the Dharma, they should simply learn to concentrate their minds, causing their body, speech, and mind to attain the characteristics of purity, and I will also protect and think of them, causing those sentient beings to quickly eliminate various obstacles.
MÄra, the evil one, will not come to destroy them, and the ninety-five kinds of non-Buddhist heretical teachers and all ghosts and spirits will also not come to disturb them.
The five hindrances will gradually become lighter, and they will be able to cultivate meditation and wisdom.

Furthermore, if sentient beings in the future, although not seeking meditation, wisdom, and the path to liberation, but encounter various calamities, poverty, suffering, and distress, they should also respectfully pay homage and make offerings, repent of their evil deeds, always make vows, and diligently chant my name with utmost sincerity at all times and in all places.
They will also quickly escape from various misfortunes and, after leaving this life, be reborn in a good place.

Furthermore, in the future, if there are lay or ordained sentient beings who wish to receive the pure and wonderful precepts, but who have previously committed grave offenses and are therefore unable to receive them, they should also practice the repentance method as described above, until they attain a sincere mind, and have good physical, verbal, and mental signs, and then they may receive [the precepts].

If those sentient beings wish to cultivate the MahÄyÄna path, seek to receive the fundamental and grave precepts of a bodhisattva, and wish to receive all the precepts of lay and ordained practitioners in general - namely,

the precepts of restraining from unwholesome actions, the precepts of cultivating wholesome dharmas, and the precepts of benefiting sentient beings - but are unable to find a good and virtuous preceptor who has a thorough understanding of the bodhisattva canon,

those who have already begun the practice should sincerely beseech the buddhas and bodhisattvas in the ten directions within the ritual arena, respectfully making offerings and requesting them to serve as their teachers and witnesses.

Single-mindedly make a vow, recite the characteristics of the precepts, first explain the ten fundamental grave precepts, and next should generally mention the three kinds of precepts, vow to receive them, and this also obtains the precepts.

Furthermore, in the future, sentient beings who wish to leave the household life, and those who have already left the household life, if they are unable to obtain a good preceptor of the precepts, and a pure assembly of monks, if their minds are doubtful and unable to properly receive the precepts, but are able to study and arouse the unsurpassed enlightened mind, and also cause their body, speech, and mind to become pure,

Those who have not yet left the household life should shave their heads, put on the Dharma robes, make the above vow, and vow to receive the three kinds of precepts of the bodhisattva precepts, and are then called fully obtaining the precepts of leaving the household life, and are called bhiká¹£us and bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s.
They should then seek the SÅ«tra Piá¹­aka of the Å›rÄvakas, and the MÄtá¹›kÄ Piá¹­aka practiced by the bodhisattvas, uphold and recite them, contemplate and practice them.
If, although having gone forth, one's age is not yet twenty, one should first vow to receive the ten fundamental precepts and receive the separate precepts of the novice monk or novice nun.
After receiving the precepts, one is also called a novice monk or novice nun.

One should then revere, make offerings, and serve those who have gone forth earlier, who have the mind to study the Great Vehicle, and who have fully received the precepts, seeking to be their teacher of reliance, asking about the precepts and training, and practicing the deportment as the novice monk or novice nun precepts.

If one is unable to meet such a person, one should only revere the Bodhisattva's practice of the MÅ«lasarvÃ¢stivÄda-vinaya, read and recite it, contemplate it, observe it, and practice it diligently, making offerings to the Three Jewels.
If a novice nun is eighteen years old, she should also vow to receive the six precepts of the Vinaya Piá¹­aka, the method of the Å›iká¹£amÄá¹‡Ä, and the entire precepts of the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«.
If the age is twenty or more, then one can receive the three types of bodhisattva precepts as mentioned above.
Then one can be called a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«.

If those sentient beings, although they study repentance, are not able to be sincere and do not obtain good signs, even if they perform the receiving of precepts, it is not called obtaining the precepts.
At that time, the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Firm Pure Faith asked the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Earth-Store:
The sincerity that you speak of, how many kinds of distinctions are there?
What kind of sincerity can obtain good signs?
The Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Earth-Store said:
Good man!
The sincerity that I speak of is roughly of two kinds.
What are the two?
The first is the initial learning and seeking of the sincere mind.
The second is the mind that is focused and accomplished with courage and vigor, the corresponding sincere mind.
One who obtains this second sincere mind can obtain good signs.
This second sincere mind also has three kinds of distinctions: lower, middle, and upper. What are the three?
First, single-minded concentration, which means to focus the mind without distraction, and the mind becomes clear and still.
Second, a courageous mind, which means to seek diligently without slacking off, and to disregard one's body and life.
Third, a profound mind, which means to accord with the Dharma and ultimately not regress.
If a person cultivates this repentance method but does not attain even the lower sincere mind, they will never be able to obtain the pure good signs.
This is called explaining the method of the second divination wheel.

If you wish to discern the differences in receiving retribution in the three periods of time, you should carve six wheels out of wood.
